page.title: 13The wood at Halligarth
page.content: The wood at Halligarth was planted in 1845 by Dr. Laurence Edmondson. A dry stone dyke was built to protect the young tree from wind and sea air.We counted 243 trees,mostly sycamores. Those in the North-West corner looked healthiest but those on the Eastern edge,nearest to the sea,were stunted and sparse. We found bluebells,white- bells,buttercups and wild orchids under the trees.Migrating birds use the wood as a shelter,to rest in and to feed in. Species noted at some time in the wood are:short-eared owl,pied fly-catcher,wood warbler,black redstart,cuckoo,collared doves,water rail,chaffinch,brambling,mistle thrush,redwing,fieldfare,hen harrier goshawk,blackcap,red-backed shrike and woodcock.
